title: When to Ship Extensibility
description: Should user-defined metrics (extensibility) be in v0.1 or v0.2?

position_a.argument: Extensibility is core to the research platform vision. Without it, v0.1 is just a browser, not a laboratory. Users should be able to define new metrics from day one.

position_b.argument: Validate the core survey explorer first. Extensibility adds complexity (sandboxing, security, UX). Ship v0.1 minimal, gather feedback, then add extensibility in v0.2 if users want it.

resolution: Defer to v0.2, but acknowledge extensibility vision in v0.1 home page pitch. v0.1 ships with 4-5 built-in metrics (lambda, gamma, dimension, period). v0.2 adds metrics SDK. Data model supports both from day one (versioned metrics structure).
implications: v0.1 timeline stays at 6-8 weeks. Home page must clearly state 'research platform' vision even though extensibility isn't live yet. Risk: users might not return for v0.2 if v0.1 doesn't deliver extensibility promise.

title: How Much to Explain on Home Page
description: Should home page explain computational irreducibility and deep research concepts, or keep it simple?

position_a.argument: Computational irreducibility is the epistemological foundation. It explains WHY we need to survey (can't predict which rules are interesting). Users should understand this.

position_b.stance: Keep home page simple, link to depth
position_b.argument: Home page should hook users, not teach theory. 'Computational irreducibility' is jargon. Lead with wonder (animations), explain method (survey), reveal vision (emergence). Link to 'About the Research' for deep explanation.

resolution: Simple home page with 4 sections: Hero (animation), The Space (262k rules), The Method (survey), The Vision (emergence). Add 'About the Research' link to separate page with computational irreducibility, topology effects, hierarchical emergence, etc.
implications: Home page appeals to wider audience (explorers + scientists). Scientists click 'About the Research' for depth. Casual users skip theory, dive into Atlas. Progressive disclosure.

title: Schema Flexibility vs Simplicity
description: Should v0.1 schema include topology/tiling/neighborhood fields, or add them later?

position_a.argument: Topology is fundamental to research vision. If we don't include it in schema now, we'll need migration later. Future-proof the data model even if initial data is single-topology.

position_b.argument: Don't build what you don't need yet. v0.1 only has flat-torus rules. Adding topology/tiling fields now is premature. Wait until v0.3 when we actually survey other topologies.

resolution: Include topology/tiling/neighborhood fields in v0.1 schema. All 22,590 existing rules get topology='flat-torus', tiling='square', neighborhood='moore'. This is cheap (just extra columns), future-proof (no migration needed for v0.3), and honest (makes universe structure explicit).
implications: v0.1 schema is slightly more complex, but migration-free. Users see topology='flat-torus' in Detail page, which educates them that topology is variable (even though only one value exists initially). v0.3 can add sphere/hex rules without schema changes.

title: Code Extensibility vs Security
description: Is user-contributed code (for metrics) safe? How to balance power and security?

position_a.argument: User-submitted JavaScript can have infinite loops, steal data, crash browsers. Even sandboxed WebWorkers have risks. Should use restricted DSL instead of full code.

position_b.argument: WebWorkers provide isolation. Add time limits (30s), no network access, read-only data. This is safe enough. Restricting to DSL limits what metrics can do (e.g., complex pattern matching requires code).

resolution: Use WebWorker sandbox with constraints: 30s timeout, no network, no DOM, read-only rule data. Provide standard utils API (simulate, detectPattern, etc). Require testing on 10 sample rules before queuing full run. Monitor for abuse, add restrictions if needed.
implications: v0.2 security model is sandbox + constraints, not restriction. Users can write powerful metrics (glider detection, hierarchy classification) but can't harm system. Trade-off: sophisticated users might hit time/capability limits. Can expand sandbox capabilities in v0.3 if needed.
